title: Divorce
intro: Hypothesis: Remarriage is permitted after the death of one's spouse.

evidence.head: Paul Advises Young Widows to Marry
evidence.short: St. Paul recommends that younger widows marry and have children.
evidence.details:
Proponents see this as proof that remarriage is permissible for a widow.

Critics may argue that this is only explicitly for young women, so it may not be allowed for everyone.

evidence.head: Levirate Marriage
evidence.short: In the Old Testament, an unmarried man who lives with his brother's family is required to marry his late brother's widow.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this gives widows a precedent for remarrying.

Critics argue that the Old Testament law is generally more permissive than that of the New Testament when it comes to divorce and remarriage, so it is not surprising that it should also allow remarriage for widows.

evidence.head: Jesus: Like Angels in Heaven
evidence.short: Jesus implies that the woman who married seven brothers in succession will no longer be married at the resurrection.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this is because people are only married until death doth them part, so a widow is no longer married.

Critics may argue that the obligation for a man to marry his brother's widow shows that the obligations of a marriage doesn't simply disappear once one of the spouses dies, and that Jesus is talking about the resurrection from the dead, not death itself.

evidence.head: Paul: Widows Are Not Bound
evidence.short: St. Paul explains that wives are bound by the law to their husband as long as he lives, but after his death, she can marry another without being called an adultress.
evidence.details:
Proponents see this as supporting a widow's right to remarry.

Critics may concede this for women, but may still argue that men can't. Others may argue that the law is irrelevant to Christian morality, and that the permanence of marriage trumps it.

evidence.head: Paul: It Is Better Not to Marry
evidence.short: St. Paul expresses a preference for celibacy over marriage.
evidence.details:
Proponents are generally comfortable with this, because a preference is not a command, and Paul allows remarriage in the same chapter.

Critics may argue that we ought to strive for the best, not settle for whatever liberty we can get away with, and so celibacy should trump the licence to remarry.

evidence.head: Marriage as Christ and the Church
evidence.short: St. Paul uses marriage as a metaphor for Christ and the Church.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this suggests one marriage is enough, because there is only one bridegroom, and remarriage would distort this pattern.

Proponents generally agree that one marriage is the ideal, but caution that the metaphor should not be taken too far.

evidence.head: Justin Martyr: Second Marriages Are Sinful
evidence.short: St. Justin Martyr (c. 155–157 AD) mentions that "those who make second marriages according to human law are sinners in the sight of our Teacher".
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this forbids remarriage for widows and widowers.

Proponents take it to be a prohibition on remarriage after divorce.

evidence.head: Church Fathers Against Remarriage
evidence.short: Some Church Fathers don't allow remarriage at all.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that these Fathers show the mind of the early Church to be against remarriage.

Proponents argue that these Fathers were overly zealous and simply wrong on this issue.
references: Athenagoras (176–177 AD): A Plea for the Christians, Chapter 33: https://www.logoslibrary.org/athenagoras/plea/33.html
Tertullian (c. 200 AD): On Modesty, Chapter XVI: https://www.tertullian.org/works/de_pudicitia.htm

evidence.head: Church Fathers For Remarriage
evidence.short: Some Church Fathers do allow remarriage for widows and widowers, many of them reluctantly.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that these fathers show the mind of the early Church to be in favour of remarriage after the death of one's spouse.

Critics argue that these Fathers were overly permissive.
references: Tertullian (c. 200 AD): To My Wife, Book II: https://tertullian.org/works/ad_uxorem.htm
Tertullian (c. 207–208 AD): Against Marcion, Book IV, Chapter 34: https://www.tertullian.org/articles/evans_marc/evans_marc_10book4_eng.htm
Clement of Alexandria (c. 199 AD – c.201 AD): Stromata, Book III, Chapter XII: https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/02103.htm (in Latin for some reason)

evidence.head: Consensus of the Church
evidence.short: The Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, the Oriental Orthodox Church, the Assyrian Church of the East, as well as most Protestant groups, all allow widows and widowers to remarry.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this weighs heavily in favour, because the judgement of the Church trumps individual Fathers.

Critics caution that it might be possible for the entire Church to be wrong.
